Title: A normal, idempotent linear operator must be self-adjoint
Content: I have been trying to solve this problem for quite a while. I am still unsure of whether any of the avenues I have pursued have been of any use. Any advice will be much appreciated. Question: Let $V$ be a finite-dimensional inner product space, and let $E$ be an idempotent linear operator on $V$ . Prove that if $EE^* = E^*E$ , then $E$ is self-adjoint. (This is essentially exercise 5(a) in sec. 80 on p.162 of Paul R. Halmos, Finite-Dimensional Vector Spaces , but Halmos didn't assume that the dimension of $V$ is finite.)
AcceptedAnswer:
If $E$ is normal, $\| E x \| = \|E^* x \|$ for all $x$.  Similarly, $I-E$ is normal,
so $\|(I-E) x\| = \|(I - E^*)x \|$.  In particular, since $(I-E)Ex = 0$, $(I-E^*)Ex = 0$, i.e. $E^* E = E$, and similarly since $E(I-E)x = 0$,  $E^*(I-E)x = 0$, i.e. $E^* E  = E^* $.  But those together say  $E = E^*$.
